thread.title: City headhunter killed by van near St Paul's after leaving her 30th birthday party
thread.title_full: City headhunter killed by van near St Paul's after leaving her 30th birthday party

author: Ben Morgan, Sophia Sleigh
title: City headhunter killed by van near St Paul's after leaving her 30th birthday party
text:
20 BST Laura Murray-Woodford was hit by a van in Ludgate Hill 
A City headhunter was knocked down by a van and killed as she left her 30th birthday party to catch a train home. 
Laura Murray-Woodford, a recruitment adviser for education charity City and Guilds, was struck as she crossed Ludgate Hill, near St Paul’s Cathedral, on October 20 last year. 
She had been celebrating her birthday in All Bar One with colleagues when she left to catch a train home to Croydon shortly after 10pm. 
Just before the crash Ms Murray-Woodford texted her husband, IT consultant Ben Kelly-Taylor, to say she would be “leaving soon”. 
Mr Kelly-Taylor grew concerned when he did not hear from her for an hour and called her phone but police answered and informed him she had been involved in an accident. 
She was pronounced dead in hospital in the early hours of October 21. Just before the crash Ms Murray-Woodford texted husband Ben Kelly-Taylor to say she would be “leaving soon" 
Mr Kelly-Taylor today told of his devastation at losing his “genuine and compassionate” wife six months after they married on his grandmother’s farm in his native Australia. 
He said: “Laura was an outgoing person. She was very socially minded and loved spending time with people. One of the words that best describes her is tenacious. 
“She wouldn’t let things get her down – she would work on them. She had a way about her of being warm and humble and making people feel comfortable. It was tragic. She deserved better than she got. 
“A lot of people think their loved ones are special but in this case it really was true. I fell more in love with Laura as time went on and loved being her boyfriend and husband. 
“We had a really short amount of time together once we had married but we had been together six years. 
“She had no reservations or doubt when she smiled – you could see she shone through. She was the same through and through – genuine and compassionate. Read more
